skill.name: ESM
skill.description: Comprehensive toolkit for protein language models including ESM3 (generative multimodal protein design across sequence, structure, and function) and ESM C (efficient protein embeddings and representations). Use this skill when working with protein sequences, structures, or function prediction; designing novel proteins; generating protein embeddings; performing inverse folding; or conducting protein engineering tasks. Supports both local model usage and cloud-based Forge API for scalable inference.
skill.summary: State-of-the-art protein language models for protein sequence generation, structure prediction, and embedding generation
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: All 319 static findings are false positives. The scanner incorrectly flagged markdown documentation patterns. The skill consists of documentation files for legitimate protein language models from EvolutionaryScale. All code examples are standard scientific workflows for protein engineering. No malicious patterns detected.

static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Scanner detected backticks in Python f-strings like f"MPRT{'_' * 10}KEND". The underscore is Python string multiplication for masked protein positions, not shell backticks. All occurrences are in markdown documentation with legitimate Python code examples.

Documentation shows hashlib.md5() for cache key generation (non-cryptographic). MD5 used to create cache keys for protein embeddings, not security purposes. Legitimate scientific documentation pattern.

Generic terms like 'command', 'control', 'track' flagged incorrectly. In context, these refer to ESM3 generation tracks (sequence/structure/function) and model control parameters, not command-and-control infrastructure.
URLs are legitimate references to forge.evolutionaryscale.ai (API platform), github.com/evolutionaryscale/esm (official repo), and science.org (published paper). Standard documentation practices.
Documentation shows standard file I/O for scientific workflows: writing PDB files, FASTA files, and cache files. Legitimate bioinformatics operations for protein engineering.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [HIGH] scripts: Dynamic code evaluation with eval()
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Scanner misclassification. The code uses model.generate() method for protein sequence generation, not Python eval(). This is a protein language model, not dynamic code execution.

Heuristic flagged 'code execution + network + credential access'. Machine learning documentation naturally combines data processing, file operations, and API calls. This is standard ML library documentation, not obfuscation. The skill is a legitimate protein engineering toolkit.

content.user_title: Generate and design proteins with ESM
content.value_statement: ESM provides state-of-the-art protein language models for understanding, generating, and designing proteins. Generate novel protein sequences, predict 3D structures, and create embeddings for downstream analysis using ESM3 for generative tasks and ESM C for efficient representation learning.
actual_capabilities: Generate novel protein sequences using ESM3 multimodal generative modeling
Predict 3D protein structures from sequences and perform inverse folding
Create high-quality protein embeddings with ESM C for downstream ML tasks
Condition protein generation on structure and function annotations
Process proteins via local models or cloud-based Forge API
Chain multiple generation steps for iterative protein design
limitations: Large ESM3 models (98B) require Forge API access, not local execution
Open weights model (1.4B) has lower quality than larger variants
Generated proteins require experimental validation before use
GPU memory requirements limit processing of very long sequences locally

use_cases.title: Design novel proteins
use_cases.description: Generate new protein sequences with desired properties using ESM3 function conditioning and chain-of-thought generation.

use_cases.title: Predict protein structures
use_cases.description: Predict 3D structures from sequences and design sequences for target structures using inverse folding.

use_cases.title: Generate protein embeddings
use_cases.description: Create rich protein representations using ESM C for classification, clustering, and transfer learning tasks.

prompt_templates.title: Basic sequence generation
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a protein sequence of 150 amino acids for a fluorescent protein. Use ESM3 with function annotations for green fluorescent protein.

prompt_templates.title: Structure prediction
prompt_templates.prompt: Predict the 3D structure for this protein sequence: MPRTKEINDAGLIVHSPQWFYK. Save the coordinates to a PDB file.

prompt_templates.title: Inverse folding
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform inverse folding on the protein structure in target_structure.pdb. Generate a sequence that folds to this structure.

prompt_templates.title: Embedding analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate ESM C embeddings for these protein sequences and perform clustering analysis to identify functional groups.

output_examples.input: Generate a 200 amino acid protein with enzymatic activity
output: Generated protein sequence with function annotation for enzymatic activity (positions 50-150)

best_practices: Start with smaller models (esm3-sm-open-v1) for prototyping before scaling to Forge API
Use chain-of-thought generation with multiple steps for complex protein designs
Cache embeddings and frequently-used results to reduce computation costs
Validate generated sequences with structure prediction or experimental assays
anti_patterns: Do not use generated proteins in wet-lab experiments without computational and experimental validation
Do not assume generated proteins are stable or functional without testing
Do not ignore biosafety implications when designing novel proteins

faq.question: What models are available in ESM?
faq.answer: ESM3 family: esm3-sm-open-v1 (1.4B, local), esm3-medium-2024-08 (7B, Forge), esm3-large-2024-03 (98B, Forge). ESM C family: esmc-300m, esmc-600m, esmc-6b.

faq.question: How do I access the Forge API?
faq.answer: Sign up at https://forge.evolutionaryscale.ai to get an API token. Use ESM3ForgeInferenceClient with your token for cloud-based inference.

faq.question: What is inverse folding?
faq.answer: Inverse folding designs a protein sequence that will fold into a given 3D structure. Use ESM3 with condition_on_coordinates_only=True.

faq.question: How do embeddings differ from generation?
faq.answer: ESM C generates fixed-length vector representations of proteins for downstream ML tasks. ESM3 generates new protein sequences, structures, or functions.

faq.question: What are function annotations?
faq.answer: Function annotations specify desired biological functions (like enzymatic activity) for generated proteins. Use FunctionAnnotation class with start/end positions.

faq.question: Are generated proteins ready for experimental use?
faq.answer: No. Generated proteins require validation through structure prediction, computational analysis, and experimental testing before any practical application.
